books.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:1
verses.text: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:2
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:3
verses.text: The Lord has heard those supplications which you, my best beloved Donatus, pour forth in His presence all the day long, and the supplications of the rest of our brethren, who by a glorious confession have obtained an everlasting crown, the reward of their faith.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:4
verses.text: Behold, all the adversaries are destroyed, and tranquillity having been re-established throughout the Roman empire, the late oppressed Church arises again, and the temple of God, overthrown by the hands of the wicked, is built with more glory than before.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:5
verses.text: For God has raised up princes to rescind the impious and sanguinary edicts of the tyrants and provide for the welfare of mankind; so that now the cloud of past times is dispelled, and peace and serenity gladden all hearts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:6
verses.text: And after the furious whirlwind and black tempest, the heavens are now become calm, and the wished-for light has shone forth; and now God, the hearer of prayer, by His divine aid has lifted His prostrate and afflicted servants from the ground, has brought to an end the united devices of the wicked, and wiped off the tears from the faces of those who mourned.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:7
verses.text: They who insulted over the Divinity, lie low; they who cast down the holy temple, are fallen with more tremendous ruin; and the tormentors of just men have poured out their guilty souls amidst plagues inflicted by Heaven, and amidst deserved tortures.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:8
verses.text: For God delayed to punish them, that, by great and marvellous examples, He might teach posterity that He alone is God, and that with fit vengeance He executes judgment on the proud, the impious, and the persecutors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:9
verses.text: Of the end of those men I have thought good to publish a narrative, that all who are afar off, and all who shall arise hereafter, may learn how the Almighty manifested His power and sovereign greatness in rooting out and utterly destroying the enemies of His name.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 1:10
verses.text: And this will become evident, when I relate who were the persecutors of the Church from the time of its first constitution, and what were the punishments by which the divine Judge, in His severity, took vengeance on them.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:2
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:3
verses.text: In the latter days of the Emperor Tiberius, in the consulship of Ruberius Geminus and Fufius Geminus, and on the tenth of the kalends of April, as I find it written, Jesus Christ was crucified by the Jews.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:4
verses.text: After He had risen again on the third day, He gathered together His apostles, whom fear, at the time of His being laid hold on, had put to flight; and while He sojourned with them forty days, He opened their hearts, interpreted to them the Scripture, which hitherto had been wrapped up in obscurity, ordained and fitted them for the preaching of His word and doctrine, and regulated all things concerning the institutions of the New Testament; and this having been accomplished, a cloud and whirlwind enveloped Him, and caught Him up from the sight of men unto heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:5
verses.text: His apostles were at that time eleven in number, to whom were added Matthias, in the room of the traitor Judas, and afterwards Paul.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:6
verses.text: Then were they dispersed throughout all the earth to preach the Gospel, as the Lord their Master had commanded them; and during twenty-five years, and until the beginning of the reign of the Emperor Nero, they occupied themselves in laying the foundations of the Church in every province and city.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:7
verses.text: And while Nero reigned, the Apostle Peter came to Rome, and, through the power of God committed unto him, wrought certain miracles, and, by turning many to the true religion, built up a faithful and stedfast temple unto the Lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:8
verses.text: When Nero heard of those things, and observed that not only in Rome, but in every other place, a great multitude revolted daily from the worship of idols, and, condemning their old ways, went over to the new religion, he, an execrable and pernicious tyrant, sprung forward to raze the heavenly temple and destroy the true faith.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:9
verses.text: He it was who first persecuted the servants of God; he crucified Peter, and slew Paul: nor did he escape with impunity; for God looked on the affliction of His people; and therefore the tyrant, bereaved of authority, and precipitated from the height of empire, suddenly disappeared, and even the burial-place of that noxious wild beast was nowhere to be seen.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 2:10
verses.text: This has led some persons of extravagant imagination to suppose that, having been conveyed to a distant region, he is still reserved alive; and to him they apply the Sibylline verses concerning  "The fugitive, who slew his own mother, being to come from the uttermost boundaries of the earth;"    as if he who was the first should also be the last persecutor, and thus prove the forerunner of Antichrist! But we ought not to believe those who, affirming that the two prophets Enoch and Elias have been translated into some remote place that they might attend our Lord when He shall come to judgment, also fancy that Nero is to appear hereafter as the forerunner of the devil, when he shall come to lay waste the earth and overthrow mankind.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3:2
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3:3
verses.text: After an interval of some years from the death of Nero, there arose another tyrant no less wicked (Domitian), who, although his government was exceedingly odious, for a very long time oppressed his subjects, and reigned in security, until at length he stretched forth his impious hands against the Lord.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3:4
verses.text: Having been instigated by evil demons to persecute the righteous people, he was then delivered into the power of his enemies, and suffered due punishment.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3:5
verses.text: To be murdered in his own palace was not vengeance ample enough: the very memory of his name was erased.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3:6
verses.text: For although he had erected many admirable edifices, and rebuilt the Capitol, and left other distinguished marks of his magnificence, yet the senate did so persecute his name, as to leave no remains of his statues, or traces of the inscriptions put up in honour of him; and by most solemn and severe decrees it branded him, even after death, with perpetual infamy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3:7
verses.text: Thus, the commands of the tyrant having been rescinded, the Church was not only restored to her former state, but she shone forth with additional splendour, and became more and more flourishing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 3:8
verses.text: And in the times that followed, while many well-deserving princes guided the helm of the Roman empire, the Church suffered no violent assaults from her enemies, and she extended her hands unto the east and unto the west, insomuch that now there was not any the most remote corner of the earth to which the divine religion had not penetrated, or any nation of manners so barbarous that did not, by being converted to the worship of God, become mild and gentle.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 4

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 4:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 4:2
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 4:3
verses.text: This long peace, however, was afterwards interrupted.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 4:4
verses.text: Decius appeared in the world, an accursed wild beast, to afflict the Church,—and who but a bad man would persecute religion? It seems as if he had been raised to sovereign eminence, at once to rage against God, and at once to fall; for, having undertaken an expedition against the Carpi, who had then possessed themselves of Dacia and Moefia, he was suddenly surrounded by the barbarians, and slain, together with great part of his army; nor could he be honoured with the rites of sepulture, but, stripped and naked, he lay to be devoured by wild beasts and birds,—a fit end for the enemy of God.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5:2
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5:3
verses.text: And presently Valerian also, in a mood alike frantic, lifted up his impious hands to assault God, and, although his time was short, shed much righteous blood.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5:4
verses.text: But God punished him in a new and extraordinary manner, that it might be a lesson to future ages that the adversaries of Heaven always receive the just recompense of their iniquities.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5:5
verses.text: He, having been made prisoner by the Persians, lost not only that power which he had exercised without moderation, but also the liberty of which be had deprived others; and he wasted the remainder of his days in the vilest condition of slavery: for Sapores, the king of the Persians, who had made him prisoner, whenever he chose to get into his carriage or to mount on horseback, commanded the Roman to stoop and present his back; then, setting his foot on the shoulders of Valerian, he said, with a smile of reproach, "This is true, and not what the Romans delineate on board or plaster".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5:6
verses.text: Valerian lived for a considerable time under the well-merited insults of his conqueror; so that the Roman name remained long the scoff and derision of the barbarians: and this also was added to the severity of his punishment, that although he had an emperor for his son, he found no one to revenge his captivity and most abject and servile state; neither indeed was he ever demanded back.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5:7
verses.text: Afterward, when he had finished this shameful life under so great dishonour, he was flayed, and his skin, stripped from the flesh, was dyed with vermilion, and placed in the temple of the gods of the barbarians, that the remembrance of a triumph so signal might be perpetuated, and that this spectacle might always be exhibited to our ambassadors, as an admonition to the Romans, that, beholding the spoils of their captived emperor in a Persian temple, they should not place too great confidence in their own strength.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 5:8
verses.text: Now since God so punished the sacrilegious, is it not strange that any one should afterward have dared to do, or even to devise, aught against the majesty of the one God, who governs and supports all things?.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 6

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 6:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 6:2
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 6:3
verses.text: Aurelian might have recollected the fate of the captived emperor, yet, being of a nature outrageous and headstrong, he forgot both his sin and its punishment, and by deeds of cruelty irritated the divine wrath.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 6:4
verses.text: He was not, however, permitted to accomplish what he had devised; for just as he began to give a loose to his rage, he was slain.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 6:5
verses.text: His bloody edicts had not yet reached the more distant provinces, when he himself lay all bloody on the earth at Caenophrurium in Thrace, assassinated by his familiar friends, who had taken up groundless suspicions against him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 6:6
verses.text: Examples of such a nature, and so numerous, ought to have deterred succeeding tyrants; nevertheless they were not only not dismayed, but, in their misdeeds against God, became more bold and presumptuous.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:2
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:3
verses.text: While Diocletian, that author of ill, and deviser of misery, was ruining all things, he could not withhold his insults, not even against God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:4
verses.text: This man, by avarice partly, and partly by timid counsels, overturned the Roman empire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:5
verses.text: For he made choice of three persons to share the government with him; and thus, the empire having been quartered, armies were multiplied, and each of the four princes strove to maintain a much more considerable military force than any sole emperor had done in times past.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:6
verses.text: There began to be fewer men who paid taxes than there were who received wages; so that the means of the husbandmen being exhausted by enormous impositions, the farms were abandoned, cultivated grounds became woodland, and universal dismay prevailed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:7
verses.text: Besides, the provinces were divided into minute portions, and many presidents and a multitude of inferior officers lay heavy on each territory, and almost on each city.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:8
verses.text: There were also many stewards of different degrees, and deputies of presidents.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:9
verses.text: Very few civil causes came before them: but there were condemnations daily, and forfeitures frequently inflicted; taxes on numberless commodities, and those not only often repeated, but perpetual, and, in exacting them, intolerable wrongs.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:10
verses.text: Whatever was laid on for the maintenance of the soldiery might have been endured; but Diocletian, through his insatiable avarice, would never allow the sums of money in his treasury to be diminished: he was constantly heaping together extraordinary aids and free gifts, that his original hoards might remain untouched and inviolable.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:11
verses.text: He also, when by various extortions he had made all things exceedingly dear, attempted by an ordinance to limit their prices.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:12
verses.text: Then much blood was shed for the veriest trifles; men were afraid to expose aught to sale, and the scarcity became more excessive and grievous than ever, until, in the end, the ordinance, after having proved destructive to multitudes, was from mere necessity abrogated.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:13
verses.text: To this there were added a certain endless passion for building, and on that account, endless exactions from the provinces for furnishing wages to labourers and artificers, and supplying carriages and whatever else was requisite to the works which he projected.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:14
verses.text: Here public halls, there a circus, here a mint, and there a workhouse for making implements of war; in one place a habitation for his empress, and in another for his daughter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:15
verses.text: Presently great part of the city was quitted, and all men removed with their wives and children, as from a town taken by enemies; and when those buildings were completed, to the destruction of whole provinces, he said, "They are not right, let them be done on another plan".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:16
verses.text: Then they were to be pulled down, or altered, to undergo perhaps a future demolition.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:17
verses.text: By such folly was he continually endeavouring to equal Nicomedia with the city Rome in magnificence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:18
verses.text: I omit mentioning how many perished on account of their possessions or wealth; for such evils were exceedingly frequent, and through their frequency appeared almost lawful.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 7:19
verses.text: But this was peculiar to him, that whenever he saw a field remarkably well cultivated, or a house of uncommon elegance, a false accusation and a capital punishment were straightway prepared against the proprietor; so that it seemed as if Diocletian could not be guilty of rapine without also shedding blood.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:2
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:3
verses.text: What was the character of his brother in empire, Maximian, called Herculius? Not unlike to that of Diocletian; and, indeed, to render their friendship so close and faithful as it was, there must have been in them a sameness of inclinations and purposes, a corresponding will and unanimity in judgment.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:4
verses.text: Herein alone they were different, that Diocletian was more avaricious and less resolute, and that Maximian, with less avarice, had a bolder spirit, prone not to good, but to evil.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:5
verses.text: For while he possessed Italy, itself the chief seat of empire, and while other very opulent provinces, such as Africa and Spain, were near at hand, he took little care to preserve those treasures which he had such fair opportunities of amassing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:6
verses.text: Whenever he stood in need of more, the richest senators were presently charged, by suborned evidences, as guilty of aspiring to the empire; so that the chief luminaries of the senate were daily extinguished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:7
verses.text: And thus the treasury, delighting in blood, overflowed with ill-gotten wealth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:8
verses.text: Add to all this the incontinency of that pestilent wretch, not only in debauching males, which is hateful and abominable, but also in the violation of the daughters of the principal men of the state; for wherever he journeyed, virgins were suddenly torn from the presence of their parents.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:9
verses.text: In such enormities he placed his supreme delight, and to indulge to the utmost his lust and flagitious desires was in his judgment the felicity of his reign.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 8:10
verses.text: I pass over Constantius, a prince unlike the others, and worthy to have had the sole government of the empire.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:2
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:3
verses.text: But the other Maximian (Galerius), chosen by Diocletian for his son-in-law, was worse, not only than those two princes whom our own times have experienced, but worse than all the bad princes of former days.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:4
verses.text: In this wild beast there dwelt a native barbarity and a savageness foreign to Roman blood; and no wonder, for his mother was born beyond the Danube, and it was an inroad of the Carpi that obliged her to cross over and take refuge in New Dacia.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:5
verses.text: The form of Galerius corresponded with his manners.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:6
verses.text: Of stature tall, full of flesh, and swollen to a horrible bulk of corpulency; by his speech, gestures, and looks, he made himself a terror to all that came near him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:7
verses.text: His father-in-law, too, dreaded him excessively.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:8
verses.text: The cause was this.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:9
verses.text: Narseus, king of the Persians, emulating the example set him by his grandfather Sapores, assembled a great army, and aimed at becoming master of the eastern provinces of the Roman empire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:10
verses.text: Diocletian, apt to be low-spirited and timorous in every commotion, and fearing a fate like that of Valerian, would not in person encounter Narseus; but he sent Galerius by the way of Armenia, while he himself halted in the eastern provinces, and anxiously watched the event.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:11
verses.text: It is a custom amongst the barbarians to take everything that belongs to them into the field.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:12
verses.text: Galerius laid an ambush for them, and easily overthrew men embarrassed with the multitude of their followers and with their baggage.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:13
verses.text: Having put Narseus to flight, and returned with much spoil, his own pride and Diocletian's fears were greatly increased.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:14
verses.text: For after this victory he rose to such a pitch of haughtiness as to reject the appellation of Caesar; and when he heard that appellation in letters addressed to him, he cried out, with a stern look and terrible voice, "How long am I to be Caesar? "Then he began to act extravagantly, insomuch that, as if he had been a second Romulus, he wished to pass for and to be called the offspring of Mars; and that he might appear the issue of a divinity, he was willing that his mother Romula should be dishonoured with the name of adulteress.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:15
verses.text: But, not to confound the chronological order of events, I delay the recital of his actions; for indeed afterwards, when Galerius got the title of emperor, his father-in-law having been divested of the imperial purple, he became altogether outrageous, and of unbounded arrogance.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 9:16
verses.text: While by such a conduct, and with such associates, Diocles—for that was the name of Diocletian before he attained sovereignty—occupied himself in subverting the commonweal, there was no evil which his crimes did not deserve: nevertheless he reigned most prosperously, as long as he forbore to defile his hands with the blood of the just; and what cause he had for persecuting them, I come now to explain.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:2
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:3
verses.text: Diocletian, as being of a timorous disposition, was a searcher into futurity, and during his abode in the East he began to slay victims, that from their livers he might obtain a prognostic of events; and while he sacrificed, some attendants of his, who were Christians, stood by, and they put the immortal sign on their foreheads.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:4
verses.text: At this the demons were chased away, and the holy rites interrupted.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:5
verses.text: The soothsayers trembled, unable to investigate the wonted marks on the entrails of the victims.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:6
verses.text: They frequently repeated the sacrifices, as if the former had been unpropitious; but the victims, slain from time to time, afforded no tokens for divination.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:7
verses.text: At length Tages, the chief of the soothsayers, either from guess or from his own observation, said, "There are profane persons here, who obstruct the rites".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:8
verses.text: Then Diocletian, in furious passion, ordered not only all who were assisting at the holy ceremonies, but also all who resided within the palace, to sacrifice, and, in case of their refusal, to be scourged.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:9
verses.text: And further, by letters to the commanding officers, he enjoined that all soldiers should be forced to the like impiety, under pain of being dismissed the service.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:10
verses.text: Thus far his rage proceeded; but at that season he did nothing more against the law and religion of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:11
verses.text: After an interval of some time he went to winter in Bithynia; and presently Galerius Caesar came thither, inflamed with furious resentment, and purposing to excite the inconsiderate old man to carry on that persecution which he had begun against the Christians.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 10:12
verses.text: I have learned that the cause of his fury was as follows.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:2
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:3
verses.text: The mother of Galerius, a woman exceedingly superstitious, was a votary of the gods of the mountains.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:4
verses.text: Being of such a character, she made sacrifices almost every day, and she feasted her servants on the meat offered to idols: but the Christians of her family would not partake of those entertainments; and while she feasted with the Gentiles, they continued in fasting and prayer.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:5
verses.text: On this account she conceived ill-will against the Christians, and by woman-like complaints instigated her son, no less superstitious than herself, to destroy them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:6
verses.text: So, during the whole winter, Diocletian and Galerius held councils together, at which no one else assisted; and it was the universal opinion that their conferences respected the most momentous affairs of the empire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:7
verses.text: The old man long opposed the fury of Galerius, and showed how pernicious it would be to raise disturbances throughout the world and to shed so much blood; that the Christians were wont with eagerness to meet death; and that it would be enough for him to exclude persons of that religion from the court and the army.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:8
verses.text: Yet he could not restrain the madness of that obstinate man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:9
verses.text: He resolved, therefore, to take the opinion of his friends.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:10
verses.text: Now this was a circumstance in the bad disposition of Diocletian, that whenever he determined to do good, he did it without advice, that the praise might be all his own; but whenever he determined to do ill, which he was sensible would be blamed, he called in many advisers, that his own fault might be imputed to other men: and therefore a few civil magistrates, and a few military commanders, were admitted to give their counsel; and the question was put to them according to priority of rank.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:11
verses.text: Some, through personal ill-will towards the Christians, were of opinion that they ought to be cut off, as enemies of the gods and adversaries of the established religious ceremonies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:12
verses.text: Others thought differently, but, having understood the will of Galerius, they, either from dread of displeasing or from a desire of gratifying him, concurred in the opinion given against the Christians.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:13
verses.text: Yet not even then could the emperor be prevailed upon to yield his assent.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:14
verses.text: He determined above all to consult his gods; and to that end he despatched a soothsayer to inquire of Apollo at Miletus, whose answer was such as might be expected from an enemy of the divine religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:15
verses.text: So Diocletian was drawn over from his purpose.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 11:16
verses.text: But although he could struggle no longer against his friends, and against Caesar and Apollo, yet still he attempted to observe such moderation as to command the business to be carried through without bloodshed; whereas Galerius would have had all persons burnt alive who refused to sacrifice.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:2
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:3
verses.text: A fit and auspicious day was sought out for the accomplishment of this undertaking; and the festival of the god Terminus, celebrated on the sevens of the kalends of March, was chosen, in preference to all others, to terminate, as it were, the Christian religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:4
verses.text: "That day, the harbinger of death, arose,  First cause of ill, and long enduring woes;"    of woes which befell not only the Christians, but the whole earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:5
verses.text: When that day dawned, in the eighth consulship of Diocletian and seventh of Maximian, suddenly, while it was yet hardly light, the prefect, together with chief commanders, tribunes, and officers of the treasury, came to the church in Nicomedia, and the gates having been forced open, they searched everywhere for an image of the Divinity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:6
verses.text: The books of the Holy Scriptures were found, and they were committed to the flames; the utensils and furniture of the church were abandoned to pillage: all was rapine, confusion, tumult.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:7
verses.text: That church, situated on rising ground, was within view of the palace; and Diocletian and Galerius stood, as if on a watch-tower, disputing long whether it ought to be set on fire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:8
verses.text: The sentiment of Diocletian prevailed, who dreaded lest, so great a fire being once kindled, some part of the city might he burnt; for there were many and large buildings that surrounded the church.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 12:9
verses.text: Then the Pretorian Guards came in battle array, with axes and other iron instruments, and having been let loose everywhere, they in a few hours levelled that very lofty edifice with the ground.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 13

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 13:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 13:2
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 13:3
verses.text: Next day an edict was published, depriving the Christians of all honours and dignities; ordaining also that, without any distinction of rank or degree, they should be subjected to tortures, and that every suit at law should be received against them; while, on the other hand, they were debarred from being plaintiffs in questions of wrong, adultery, or theft; and, finally, that they should neither be capable of freedom, nor have right of suffrage.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 13:4
verses.text: A certain person tore down this edict, and cut it in pieces, improperly indeed, but with high spirit, saying in scorn, "These are the triumphs of Goths and Sarmatians".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 13:5
verses.text: Having been instantly seized and brought to judgment, he was not only tortured, but burnt alive, in the forms of law; and having displayed admirable patience under sufferings, he was consumed to ashes.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:2
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:3
verses.text: But Galerius, not satisfied with the tenor of the edict, sought in another way to gain on the emperor.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:4
verses.text: That he might urge him to excess of cruelty in persecution, he employed private emissaries to set the palace on fire; and some part of it having been burnt, the blame was laid on the Christians as public enemies; and the very appellation of Christian grew odious on account of that fire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:5
verses.text: It was said that the Christians, in concert with the eunuchs, had plotted to destroy the princes; and that both of the princes had well-nigh been burnt alive in their own palace.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:6
verses.text: Diocletian, shrewd and intelligent as he always chose to appear, suspected nothing of the contrivance, but, inflamed with anger, immediately commanded that all his own domestics should be tortured to force a confession of the plot.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:7
verses.text: He sat on his tribunal, and saw innocent men tormented by fire to make discovery.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:8
verses.text: All magistrates, and all who had superintendency in the imperial palace, obtained special commissions to administer the torture; and they strove with each other who should be first in bringing to light the conspiracy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:9
verses.text: No circumstances, however, of the fact were detected anywhere; for no one applied the torture to any domestics of Galerius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:10
verses.text: He himself was ever with Diocletian, constantly urging him, and never allowing the passions of the inconsiderate old man to cool.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:11
verses.text: Then, after an interval of fifteen days, he attempted a second fire; but that was perceived quickly, and extinguished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:12
verses.text: Still, however, its author remained unknown.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 14:13
verses.text: On that very day, Galerius, who in the middle of winter had prepared for his departure, suddenly hurried out of the city, protesting that he fled to escape being burnt alive.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:2
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:3
verses.text: And now Diocletian raged, not only against his own domestics, but indiscriminately against all; and he began by forcing his daughter Valeria and his wife Prisca to be polluted by sacrificing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:4
verses.text: Eunuchs, once the most powerful, and who had chief authority at court and with the emperor, were slain.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:5
verses.text: Presbyters and other officers of the Church were seized, without evidence by witnesses or confession, condemned, and together with their families led to execution.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:6
verses.text: In burning alive, no distinction of sex or age was regarded; and because of their great multitude, they were not burnt one after another, but a herd of them were encircled with the same fire; and servants, having millstones tied about their necks, were cast into the sea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:7
verses.text: Nor was the persecution less grievous on the rest of the people of God; for the judges, dispersed through all the temples, sought to compel every one to sacrifice.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:8
verses.text: The prisons were crowded; tortures, hitherto unheard of, were invented; and lest justice should be inadvertently administered to a Christian, altars were placed in the courts of justice, hard by the tribunal, that every litigant might offer incense before his cause could be heard.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:9
verses.text: Thus judges were no otherwise approached than divinities.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:10
verses.text: Mandates also had gone to Maximian Herculius and Constantius, requiring their concurrence in the execution of the edicts; for in matters even of such mighty importance their opinion was never once asked.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:11
verses.text: Herculius, a person of no merciful temper, yielded ready obedience, and enforced the edicts throughout his dominions of Italy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 15:12
verses.text: Constantius, on the other hand, lest he should have seemed to dissent from the injunctions of his superiors, permitted the demolition of churches,—mere walls, and capable of being built up again,—but he preserved entire that true temple of God, which is the human body.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:2
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:3
verses.text: Thus was all the earth afflicted; and from east to west, except in the territories of Gaul, three ravenous wild beasts continued to rage.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:4
verses.text: "Had I a hundred mouths, a hundred tongues,  A voice of brass, and adamantine lungs,  Not half the dreadful scene could I disclose,"    or recount the punishments inflicted by the rulers in every province on religious and innocent men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:5
verses.text: But what need of a particular recital of those things, especially to you, my best beloved Donatus, who above all others was exposed to the storm of that violent persecution? For when you had fallen into the hands of the prefect Flaccinian, no puny murderer, and afterwards of Hierocles, who from a deputy became president of Bithynia, the author and adviser of the persecution, and last of all into the hands of his successor Priscillian, you displayed to mankind a pattern of invincible magnanimity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:6
verses.text: Having been nine times exposed to racks and diversified torments, nine times by a glorious profession of your faith you foiled the adversary; in nine combats you subdued the devil and his chosen soldiers; and by nine victories you triumphed over this world and its terrors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:7
verses.text: How pleasing the spectacle to God, when He beheld you a conqueror, yoking in your chariot not white horses, nor enormous elephants, but those very men who had led captive the nations! After this sort to lord it over the lords of the earth is triumph indeed! Now, by your valour were they conquered, when you set at defiance their flagitious edicts, and, through stedfast faith and the fortitude of your soul, you routed all the vain terrors of tyrannical authority.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:8
verses.text: Against you neither scourges, nor iron claws, nor fire, nor sword, nor various kinds of torture, availed aught; and no violence could bereave you of your fidelity and persevering resolution.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:9
verses.text: This it is to be a disciple of God, and this it is to be a soldier of Christ; a soldier whom no enemy can dislodge, or wolf snatch, from the heavenly camp; no artifice ensnare, or pain of body subdue, or torments overthrow.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:10
verses.text: At length, after those nine glorious combats, in which the devil was vanquished by you, he dared not to enter the lists again with one whom, by repeated trials, he had found unconquerable; and he abstained from challenging you any more, lest you should have laid hold on the garland of victory already stretched out to you; an unfading garland, which, although you have not at present received it, is laid up in the kingdom of the Lord for your virtue and deserts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 16:11
verses.text: But let us now return to the course of our narrative.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:2
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:3
verses.text: The wicked plan having been carried into execution, Diocletian, whom prosperity had now abandoned, set out instantly for Rome, there to celebrate the commencement of the twentieth year of his reign.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:4
verses.text: That solemnity was performed on the twelfth of the kalends of December; and suddenly the emperor, unable to bear the Roman freedom of speech, peevishly and impatiently burst away from the city.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:5
verses.text: The kalends of January approached, at which day the consulship, for the ninth time, was to be offered to him; yet, rather than continue thirteen days longer in Rome, he chose that his first appearance as consul should be at Ravenna.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:6
verses.text: Having, however, begun his journey in winter, amidst intense cold and incessant rains, he contracted a slight but lingering disease: it harassed him without intermission, so that he was obliged for the most part to be carried in a litter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:7
verses.text: Then, at the close of summer, he made a circuit along the banks of the Danube, and so came to Nicomedia.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:8
verses.text: His disease had now become more grievous and oppressing; yet he caused himself to be brought out, in order to dedicate that circus which, at the conclusion of the twentieth year of his reign, he had erected.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:9
verses.text: Immediately he grew so languid and feeble, that prayers for his life were put up to all the gods.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:10
verses.text: Then suddenly, on the ides of December, there was heard in the palace sorrow, and weeping, and lamentation, and the courtiers ran to and fro; there was silence throughout the city, and a report went of the death, and even of the burial, of Diocletian: but early on the morrow it was suddenly rumoured that he still lived.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:11
verses.text: At this the countenance of his domestics and courtiers changed from melancholy to gay.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:12
verses.text: Nevertheless there were who suspected his death to be kept secret until the arrival of Galerius Caesar, lest in the meanwhile the soldiery should attempt some change in the government; and this suspicion grew so universal, that no one would believe the emperor alive, until, on the kalends of March, he appeared in public, but so wan, his illness having lasted almost a year, as hardly to be known again.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 17:13
verses.text: The fit of stupor, resembling death, happened on the ides of December; and although he in some measure recovered, yet he never attained to perfect health again, for he became disordered in his judgment, being at certain times insane and at others of sound mind.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:2
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:3
verses.text: Within a few days Galerius Caesar arrived, not to congratulate his father-in-law on the re-establishment of his health, but to force him to resign the empire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:4
verses.text: Already he had urged Maximian Herculius to the like purpose, and by the alarm of civil wars terrified the old man into compliance; and he now assailed Diocletian.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:5
verses.text: At first, in gentle and friendly terms, he said that age and growing infirmities disabled Diocletian for the charge of the commonweal, and that he had need to give himself some repose after his labours.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:6
verses.text: Galerius, in confirmation of his argument, produced the example of Nerva, who laid the weight of empire on Trajan.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:7
verses.text: But Diocletian made answer, that it was unfit for one who had held a rank, eminent above all others and conspicuous, to sink into the obscurity of a low station; neither indeed was it safe, because in the course of so long a reign he must unavoidably have made many enemies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:8
verses.text: That the case of Nerva was very different: he, after having reigned a single year, felt himself, either from age or from inexperience in business, unequal to affairs so momentous, and therefore threw aside the helm of government, and returned to that private life in which he had already grown old.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:9
verses.text: But Diocletian added, that if Galerius wished for the title of emperor, there was nothing to hinder its being conferred on him and Constantius, as well as on Maximian Herculius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:10
verses.text: Galerius, whose imagination already grasped at the whole empire, saw that little but an unsubstantial name would accrue to him from this proposal, and therefore replied that the settlement made by Diocletian himself ought to be inviolable; a settlement which provided that there should be two of higher rank vested with supreme power, and two others of inferior, to assist them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:11
verses.text: Easily might concord be preserved between two equals, never amongst four; that he, if Diocletian would not resign, must consult his own interests, so as to remain no longer in an inferior rank, and the last of that rank; that for fifteen years past he had been confined, as an exile, to Illyricum and the banks of the Danube, perpetually struggling against barbarous nations, while others, at their ease, governed dominions more extensive than his, and better civilized.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:12
verses.text: Diocletian already knew, by letters from Maximian Herculius, all that Galerius had spoken at their conference, and also that he was augmenting his army; and now, on hearing his discourse, the spiritless old man burst into tears, and said, "Be it as you will".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:13
verses.text: It remained to choose Caesars by common consent.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:14
verses.text: "But," said Galerius, "why ask the advice of Maximian and Constantius, since they must needs acquiesce in whatever we do?"—"Certainly they will," replied Diocletian, "for we must elect their sons".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:15
verses.text: Now Maximian Herculius had a son, Maxentius, married to the daughter of Galerius, a man of bad and mischievous dispositions, and so proud and stubborn withal, that he would never pay the wonted obeisance either to his father or father-in-law, and on that account he was hated by them both.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:16
verses.text: Constantius also had a son, Constantine, a young man of very great worth, and well meriting the high station of Caesar.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:17
verses.text: The distinguished comeliness of his figure, his strict attention to all military duties, his virtuous demeanour and singular affability, had endeared him to the troops, and made him the choice of every individual.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:18
verses.text: He was then at court, having long before been created by Diocletian a tribune of the first order.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:19
verses.text: "What is to be done?" said Galerius, "for that Maxentius deserves not the office.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:20
verses.text: He who, while yet a private man, has treated me with contumely, how will he act when once he obtains power?"—"But Constantine is amiable, and will so rule as hereafter, in the opinion of mankind, to surpass the mild virtues of his father".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:21
verses.text: —"Be it so, if my inclinations and judgment are to be disregarded.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:22
verses.text: Men ought to be appointed who are at my disposal, who will dread me, and never do anything unless by my orders".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:23
verses.text: —"Whom then shall we appoint?"—"Severus".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:24
verses.text: —"How! that dancer, that habitual drunkard, who turns night into day, and day into night?"—"He deserves the office, for he has approved himself a faithful paymaster and purveyor of the army; and, indeed, I have already despatched him to receive the purple from the hands of Maximian".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:25
verses.text: —"Well, I consent; but whom else do you suggest?"—"Him," said Galerius, pointing out Daia, a young man, half-barbarian.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:26
verses.text: Now Galerius had lately bestowed part of his own name on that youth, and called him Maximin, in like manner as Diocletian formerly bestowed on Galerius the name of Maximian, for the omen's sake, because Maximian Herculius had served him with unshaken fidelity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:27
verses.text: —"Who is that you present?"—"A kinsman of mine".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:28
verses.text: —"Alas!" said Diocletian, heaving a deep sigh, "you do not propose men fit for the charge of public affairs!"—"I have tried them".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 18:29
verses.text: —"Then do you look to it, who are about to assume the administration of the empire: as for me, while I continued emperor, long and diligent have been my labours in providing for the security of the commonweal; and now, should anything disastrous ensue, the blame will not be mine".

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:2
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:3
verses.text: Matters having been thus concerted, Diocletian and Galerius went in procession to publish the nomination of Caesars.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:4
verses.text: Every one looked at Constantine; for there was no doubt that the choice would fall on him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:5
verses.text: The troops present, as well as the chief soldiers of the other legions, who had been summoned to the solemnity, fixed their eyes on Constantine, exulted in the hope of his approaching election, and occupied themselves in prayers for his prosperity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:6
verses.text: Near three miles from Nicomedia there is an eminence, on the summit of which Galerius formerly received the purple; and there a pillar, with the statue of Jupiter, was placed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:7
verses.text: Thither the procession went.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:8
verses.text: An assembly of the soldiers was called.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:9
verses.text: Diocletian, with tears, harangued them, and said that he was become infirm, that he needed repose after his fatigues, and that he would resign the empire into hands more vigorous and able, and at the same time appoint new Caesars.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:10
verses.text: The spectators, with the utmost earnestness, waited for the nomination.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:11
verses.text: Suddenly he declared that the Caesars were Severus and Maximin.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:12
verses.text: The amazement was universal.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:13
verses.text: Constantine stood near in public view, and men began to question amongst themselves whether his name too had not been changed into Maximin; when, in the sight of all, Galerius, stretching back his hand, put Constantine aside, and drew Daia forward, and, having divested him of the garb of a private person, set him in the most conspicuous place.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:14
verses.text: All men wondered who he could be, and from whence he came; but none ventured to interpose or move objections, so confounded were their minds at the strange and unlooked-for event.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:15
verses.text: Diocletian took off his purple robe, put it on Daia, and resumed his own original name of Diocles.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 19:16
verses.text: He descended from the tribunal, and passed through Nicomedia in a chariot; and then this old emperor, like a veteran soldier freed from military service, was dismissed into his own country; while Daia, lately taken from the tending of cattle in forests to serve as a common soldier, immediately made one of the life-guard, presently a tribune, and next day Caesar, obtained authority to trample under foot and oppress the empire of the East; a person ignorant alike of war and of civil affairs, and from a herdsman become a leader of armies.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:2
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:3
verses.text: Galerius having effected the expulsion of the two old men, began to consider himself alone as the sovereign of the Roman empire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:4
verses.text: Necessity had required the appointment of Constantius to the first rank; but Galerius made small account of one who was of an easy temper, and of health declining and precarious.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:5
verses.text: He looked for the speedy death of Constantius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:6
verses.text: And although that prince should recover, it seemed not difficult to force him to put off the imperial purple; for what else could he do, if pressed by his three colleagues to abdicate? Galerius had Licinius ever about his person, his old and intimate acquaintance, and his earliest companion in arms, whose counsels he used in the management of all affairs; yet he would not nominate Licinius to the dignity of Caesar, with the title of son, for he purposed to nominate him, in the room of Constantius, to the dignity of emperor, with the title of brother, while he himself might hold sovereign authority, and rule over the whole globe with unbounded licence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:7
verses.text: After that, he meant to have solemnized the vicennial festival; to have conferred on his son Candidianus, then a boy of nine years of age, the office of Caesar; and, in conclusion, to have resigned, as Diocletian had done.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:8
verses.text: And thus, Licinius and Severus being emperors, and Maximin and Candidianus in the next station of Caesars, he fancied that, environed as it were by an impregnable wall, he should lead an old age of security and peace.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 20:9
verses.text: Such were his projects; but God, whom he had made his adversary, frustrated all those imaginations.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:2
verses.text: XXI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:3
verses.text: Having thus attained to the highest power, he bent his mind to afflict that empire into which he had opened his way.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:4
verses.text: It is the manner and practice of the Persians for the people to yield themselves slaves to their kings, and for the kings to treat their people as slaves.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:5
verses.text: This flagitious man, from the time of his victories over the Persians, was not ashamed incessantly to extol such an institution, and he resolved to establish it in the Roman dominions; and because he could not do this by an express law, he so acted, in imitation of the Persian kings, as to bereave men of their liberties.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:6
verses.text: He first of all degraded those whom he meant to punish; and then not only were inferior magistrates put to the torture by him, but also the chief men in cities, and persons of the most eminent rank, and this too in matters of little moment, and in civil questions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:7
verses.text: Crucifixion was the punishment ready prepared in capital cases; and for lesser crimes, fetters.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:8
verses.text: Matrons of honourable station were dragged into workhouses; and when any man was to be scourged, there were four posts fixed in the ground, and to them he was tied, after a manner unknown in the chastisement of slaves.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:9
verses.text: What shall I say of his apartment for sport, and of his favourite diversions? He kept bears, most resembling himself in fierceness and bulk, whom he had collected together during the course of his reign.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:10
verses.text: As often as he chose to indulge his humour, he ordered some particular bear to be brought in, and men were thrown to that savage animal, rather to be swallowed up than devoured; and when their limbs were torn asunder, he laughed with excessive complacency: nor did he ever sup without being spectator of the effusion of human blood.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:11
verses.text: Men of private station were condemned to be burnt alive; and he began this mode of execution by edicts against the Christians, commanding that, after torture and condemnation, they should be burnt at a slow fire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:12
verses.text: They were fixed to a stake, and first a moderate flame was applied to the soles of their feet, until the muscles, contracted by burning, were torn from the bones; then torches, lighted and put out again, were directed to all the members of their bodies, so that no part had any exemption.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:13
verses.text: Meanwhile cold water was continually poured on their faces, and their mouths moistened, lest, by reason of their jaws being parched, they should expire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:14
verses.text: At length they did expire, when, after many hours, the violent heat had consumed their skin and penetrated into their intestines.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 21:15
verses.text: The dead carcases were laid on a funeral pile, and wholly burnt; their bones were gathered, ground to powder, and thrown into the river, or into the sea.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:2
verses.text: XXII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:3
verses.text: And now that cruelty, which he had learned in torturing the Christians, became habitual, and he exercised it against all men indiscriminately.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:4
verses.text: He was not wont to inflict the slighter sorts of punishment, as to banish, to imprison, or to send criminals to work in the mines; but to burn, to crucify, to expose to wild beasts, were things done daily, and without hesitation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:5
verses.text: For smaller offences, those of his own household and his stewards were chastised with lances, instead of rods; and, in great offences, to be beheaded was an indulgence shown to very few; and it seemed as a favour, on account of old services, when one was permitted to die in the easiest manner.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:6
verses.text: But these were slight evils in the government of Galerius, when compared with what follows.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:7
verses.text: For eloquence was extinguished, pleaders cut off, and the learned in the laws either exiled or slain.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:8
verses.text: Useful letters came to be viewed in the same light as magical and forbidden arts; and all who possessed them were trampled upon and execrated, as if they had been hostile to government, and public enemies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 22:9
verses.text: Law was dissolved, and unbounded licence permitted to judges,—to judges chosen from amongst the soldiery, rude and illiterate men, and let loose upon the provinces, without assessors to guide or control them.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:2
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:3
verses.text: But that which gave rise to public and universal calamity, was the tax imposed at once on each province and city.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:4
verses.text: Surveyors having been spread abroad, and occupied in a general and severe scrutiny, horrible scenes were exhibited, like the outrages of victorious enemies, and the wretched state of captives.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:5
verses.text: Each spot of ground was measured, vines and fruit-trees numbered, lists taken of animals of every kind, and a capitation-roll made up.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:6
verses.text: In cities, the common people, whether residing within or without the walls, were assembled, the market-places filled with crowds of families, all attended with their children and slaves, the noise of torture and scourges resounded, sons were hung on the rack to force discovery of the effects of their fathers, the most trusty slaves compelled by pain to bear witness against their masters, and wives to bear witness against their husbands, In default of all other evidence, men were tortured to speak against themselves; and no sooner did agony oblige them to acknowledge what they had not, but those imaginary effects were noted down in the lists.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:7
verses.text: Neither youth, nor old age, nor sickness, afforded any exemption.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:8
verses.text: The diseased and the infirm were carried in; the age of each was estimated; and, that the capitation-tax might be enlarged, years were added to the young and struck off from the old.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:9
verses.text: General lamentation and sorrow prevailed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:10
verses.text: Whatever, by the laws of war, conquerors had done to the conquered, the like did this man presume to perpetrate against Romans and the subjects of Rome, because his forefathers had been made liable to a like tax imposed by the victorious Trajan, as a penalty on the Dacians for their frequent rebellions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:11
verses.text: After this, money was levied for each head, as if a price had been paid for liberty to exist; yet full trust was not reposed on the same set of surveyors, but others and others still were sent round to make further discoveries; and thus the tributes were redoubled, not because the new surveyors made any fresh discoveries, but because they added at pleasure to the former rates, lest they should seem to have been employed to no purpose.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:12
verses.text: Meanwhile the number of animals decreased, and men died; nevertheless taxes were paid even for the dead, so that no one could either live or cease to live without being subject to impositions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:13
verses.text: There remained mendicants alone, from whom nothing could be exacted, and whom their misery and wretchedness secured from ill-treatment.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:14
verses.text: But this pious man had compassion on them, and determining that they should remain no longer in indigence, he caused them all to be assembled, put on board vessels, and sunk in the sea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 23:15
verses.text: So merciful was he in making provision that under his administration no man should want! And thus, while he took effectual measures that none, under the reigned pretext of poverty, should elude the tax, he put to death a multitude of real wretches, in violation of every law of humanity.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:2
verses.text: XXIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:3
verses.text: Already the judgment of God approached him, and that season ensued in which his fortunes began to droop and to waste away.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:4
verses.text: While occupied in the manner that I have described above, he did not set himself to subvert or expel Constantius, but waited for his death, not imagining, however, that it was so nigh.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:5
verses.text: Constantius, having become exceedingly ill, wrote to Galerius, and requested that his son Constantine might be sent to see him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:6
verses.text: He had made a like request long before, but in vain; for Galerius meant nothing less than to grant it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:7
verses.text: On the contrary, he laid repeated snares for the life of that young man, because he durst not use open violence, lest he should stir up civil wars against himself, and incur that which he most dreaded, the hate and resentment of the army.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:8
verses.text: Under pretence of manly exercise and recreation, he made him combat with wild beasts: but this device was frustrated; for the power of God protected Constantine, and in the very moment of jeopardy rescued him from the hands of Galerius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:9
verses.text: At length, Galerius, when he could no longer avoid complying with the request of Constantius, one evening gave Constantine a warrant to depart, and commanded him to set out next morning with the imperial despatches.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:10
verses.text: Galerius meant either to find some pretext for detaining Constantine, or to forward orders to Severus for arresting him on the road.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:11
verses.text: Constantine discerned his purpose; and therefore, after supper, when the emperor was gone to rest, he hasted away, carried off from the principal stages all the horses maintained at the public expense, and escaped.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:12
verses.text: Next day the emperor, having purposely remained in his bed-chamber until noon, ordered Constantine to be called into his presence; but he learnt that Constantine had set out immediately after supper.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:13
verses.text: Outrageous with passion, he ordered horses to be made ready, that Constantine might be pursued and dragged back; and hearing that all the horses had been carried off from the great road, he could hardly refrain from tears.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:14
verses.text: Meanwhile Constantine, journeying with incredible rapidity, reached his father, who was already about to expire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:15
verses.text: Constantius recommended his son to the soldiers, delivered the sovereign authority into his hands, and then died, as his wish had long been, in peace and quiet.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 24:16
verses.text: Constantine Augustus, having assumed the government, made it his first care to restore the Christians to the exercise of their worship and to their God; and so began his administration by reinstating the holy religion.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25:2
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25:3
verses.text: Some few days after, the portrait of Constantine, adorned with laurels, was brought to the pernicious wild beast, that, by receiving that symbol, he might acknowledge Constantine in the quality of emperor.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25:4
verses.text: He hesitated long whether to receive it or not, and he was about to commit both the portrait and its bearer to the flames, but his confidants dissuaded him from a resolution so frantic.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25:5
