verses.text: They admonished him of the danger, and they represented that, if Constantine came with an armed force, all the soldiers, against whose inclination obscure or unknown Caesars had been created, would acknowledge him, and crowd eagerly to his standard.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25:6
verses.text: So Galerius, although with the utmost unwillingness, accepted the portrait, and sent the imperial purple to Constantine, that he might seem of his own accord to have received that prince into partnership of power with him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25:7
verses.text: And now his plans were deranged, and he could not, as he intended formerly, admit Licinius, without exceeding the limited number of emperors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 25:8
verses.text: But this he devised, that Severus, who was more advanced in life, should be named emperor, and that Constantine, instead of the title of emperor, to which he had been named, should receive that of Caesar in common with Maximin Daia, and so be degraded from the second place to the fourth.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:2
verses.text: XXVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:3
verses.text: Things seemed to be arranged in some measure to the satisfaction of Galerius, when another alarm was brought, that his son-in-law Maxentius had been declared emperor at Rome.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:4
verses.text: The cause was this: Galerius having resolved by permanent taxes to devour the empire, soared to such extravagance in folly, as not to allow an exemption from that thraldom even to the Roman people.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:5
verses.text: Tax-gatherers therefore were appointed to go to Rome, and make out lists of the citizens.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:6
verses.text: Much about the same time Galerius had reduced the Pretorian Guards.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:7
verses.text: There remained at Rome a few soldiers of that body, who, profiting of the opportunity, put some magistrates to death, and, with the acquiescence of the tumultuary populace, clothed Maxentius in the imperial purple.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:8
verses.text: Galerius, on receiving this news, was disturbed at the strangeness of the event, but not much dismayed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:9
verses.text: He hated Maxentius, and he could not bestow on him the dignity of Caesar already enjoyed by two (Daia and Constantine); besides, he thought it enough for him to have once bestowed that dignity against his inclination.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:10
verses.text: So he sent for Severus, exhorted him to regain his dominion and sovereignty, and he put under his command that army which Maximian Herculius had formerly commanded, that he might attack Maxentius at Rome.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:11
verses.text: There the soldiers of Maximian had been oftentimes received with every sort of luxurious accommodation, so that they were not only interested to preserve the city, but they also longed to fix their residence in it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:12
verses.text: Maxentius well knew the enormity of his own offences; and although he had as it were an hereditary claim to the services of his father's army, and might have hoped to draw it over to himself, yet he reflected that this consideration might occur to Galerius also, and induce him to leave Severus in Illyricum, and march in person with his own army against Rome.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:13
verses.text: Under such apprehensions, Maxentius sought to protect himself from the danger that hung over him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:14
verses.text: To his father, who since his abdication resided in Campania, he sent the purple, and saluted him again Augustus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:15
verses.text: Maximian, given to change, eagerly resumed that purple of which he had unwillingly divested himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:16
verses.text: Meanwhile Severus marched on, and with his troops approached the walls of the city.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:17
verses.text: Presently the soldiers raised up their ensigns, abandoned Severus, and yielded themselves to Maxentius, against whom they had come.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:18
verses.text: What remained but flight for Severus, thus deserted? He was encountered by Maximian, who had resumed the imperial dignity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:19
verses.text: On this he took refuge in Ravenna, and shut himself up there with a few soldiers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 26:20
verses.text: But perceiving that he was about to be delivered up, he voluntarily surrendered himself, and restored the purple to him from whom he had received it; and after this he obtained no other grace but that of an easy death, for he was compelled to open his veins, and in that gentle manner expired.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:2
verses.text: XXVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:3
verses.text: But Maximian, who knew the outrageous temper of Galerius, began to consider that, fired with rage on hearing of the death of Severus, he would march into Italy, and that possibly he might be joined by Daia, and so bring into the field forces too powerful to be resisted.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:4
verses.text: Having therefore fortified Rome, and made diligent provision for a defensive war, Maximian went into Gaul, that he might give his younger daughter Fausta in marriage to Constantine, and thus win over that prince to his interest.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:5
verses.text: Meantime Galerius assembled his troops, invaded Italy, and advanced towards Rome, resolving to extinguish the senate and put the whole people to the sword.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:6
verses.text: But he found everything shut and fortified against him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:7
verses.text: There was no hope of carrying the place by storm, and to besiege it was an arduous undertaking; for Galerius had not brought with him an army sufficient to invest the walls.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:8
verses.text: Probably, having never seen Rome, he imagined it to be little superior in size to those cities with which be was acquainted.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:9
verses.text: But some of his legions, detesting the wicked enterprise of a father against his son-in-law, and of Romans against Rome, renounced his authority, and carried over their ensigns to the enemy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:10
verses.text: Already had his remaining soldiers begun to waver, when Galerius, dreading a fate like that of Severus, and having his haughty spirit broken and humiliated, threw himself at the feet of his soldiers, and continued to beseech them that he might not be delivered to the foe, until, by the promise of mighty largesses, he prevailed on them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:11
verses.text: Then he retreated from Rome, and fled in great disorder.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:12
verses.text: Easily might he have been cut off in his flight, had any one pursued him even with a small body of troops.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:13
verses.text: He was aware of his danger, and allowed his soldiers to disperse themselves, and to plunder and destroy far and wide, that, if there were any pursuers, they might be deprived of all means of subsistence in a ruined country.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:14
verses.text: So the parts of Italy through which that pestilent band took its course were wasted, all things pillaged, matrons forced, virgins violated, parents and husbands compelled by torture to disclose where they had concealed their goods, and their wives and daughters; flocks and herds of cattle were driven off like spoils taken from barbarians.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:15
verses.text: And thus did he, once a Roman emperor, but now the ravager of Italy, retire into his own territories, after having afflicted all men indiscriminately with the calamities of war.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 27:16
verses.text: Long ago, indeed, and at the very time of his obtaining sovereign power, he had avowed himself the enemy of the Roman name; and he proposed that the empire should be called, not the Roman, but the Dacian empire.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:2
verses.text: XXVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:3
verses.text: After the flight of Galerius, Maximian, having returned from Gaul, held authority in common with his son; but more obedience was yielded to the young man than to the old: for Maxentius had most power, and had been longest in possession of it; and it was to him that Maximian owed on this occasion the imperial dignity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:4
verses.text: The old man was impatient at being denied the exercise of uncontrolled sovereignty, and envied his son with a childish spirit of rivalry; and therefore he began to consider how he might expel Maxentius and resume his ancient dominion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:5
verses.text: This appeared easy, because the soldiers who deserted Severus had originally served in his own army.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:6
verses.text: He called an assembly of the people of Rome, and of the soldiers, as if he had been to make an harangue on the calamitous situation of public affairs.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:7
verses.text: After having spoken much on that subject, he stretched his hands towards his son, charged him as author of all ills and prime cause of the calamities of the state, and then tore the purple from his shoulders.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:8
verses.text: Maxentius, thus stripped, leaped headlong from the tribunal, and was received into the arms of the soldiers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 28:9
verses.text: Their rage and clamour confounded the unnatural old man, and, like another Tarquin the Proud, he was driven from Rome.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:2
verses.text: XXIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:3
verses.text: Then Maximian returned into Gaul; and after having made some stay in those quarters, he went to Galerius, the enemy of his son, that they might confer together, as he pretended, about the settlement of the commonweal; but his true purpose was, under colour of reconciliation, to find an opportunity of murdering Galerius, and of seizing his share of the empire, instead of his own, from which he had been everywhere excluded.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:4
verses.text: Diocles was at the court of Galerius when Maximian arrived; for Galerius, meaning now to invest Licinius with the ensigns of supreme power in the room of Severus, had lately sent for Diocles to be present at the solemnity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:5
verses.text: So it was performed in presence both of him and of Maximian; and thus there were six who ruled the empire at one and the same time.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:6
verses.text: Now the designs of Maximian having been frustrated, he took flight, as he had done twice before, and returned into Gaul, with a heart full of wickedness, and intending by treacherous devices to overreach Constantine, who was not only his own son-in-law, but also the child of his son-in-law; and that he might the more successfully deceive, he laid aside the imperial purple.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:7
verses.text: The Franks had taken up arms.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:8
verses.text: Maximian advised the unsuspecting Constantine not to lead all his troops against them, and he said that a few soldiers would suffice to subdue those barbarians.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:9
verses.text: He gave this advice that an army might be left for him to win over to himself, and that Constantine, by reason of his scanty forces, might be overpowered.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:10
verses.text: The young prince believed the advice to be judicious, because given by an aged and experienced commander; and he followed it, because given by a father-in-law.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:11
verses.text: He marched, leaving the most considerable part of his forces behind.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:12
verses.text: Maximian waited a few days; and as soon as, by his calculation, Constantine had entered the territory of the barbarians, he suddenly resumed the imperial purple, seized the public treasures, after his wont made ample donatives to the soldiery, and feigned that such disasters had befallen Constantine as soon after befell himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:13
verses.text: Constantine was presently informed of those events, and, by marches astonishingly rapid, he flew back with his army.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:14
verses.text: Maximian, not yet prepared to oppose him, was overpowered at unawares, and the soldiers returned to their duty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:15
verses.text: Maximian had possessed himself of Marseilles (he fled thither), and shut the gates.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:16
verses.text: Constantine drew nigh, and seeing Maximian on the walls, addressed him in no harsh or hostile language, and demanded what he meant, and what it was that he wanted, and why he had acted in a way so peculiarly unbecoming him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:17
verses.text: But Maximian from the walls incessantly uttered abuse and curses against Constantine.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:18
verses.text: Then, of a sudden, the gates on the opposite side having been unbarred, the besiegers were admitted into the city.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 29:19
verses.text: The rebel emperor, and unnatural parent and a perfidious father-in-law, was dragged into the presence of Constantine, heard a recital made of his crimes, was divested of his imperial robe, and, after this reprimand, obtained his life.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:2
verses.text: XXX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:3
verses.text: Maximian, having thus forfeited the respect due to an emperor and a father-in-law, grew impatient at his abased condition, and, emboldened by impunity, formed new plots against Constantine.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:4
verses.text: He addressed himself to his daughter Fausta, and, as well by entreaties as by the soothing of flattery, solicited her to betray her husband.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:5
verses.text: He promised to obtain for her a more honourable alliance than that with Constantine; and he requested her to allow the bed-chamber of the emperor to be left open, and to be slightly guarded.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:6
verses.text: Fausta undertook to do whatever he asked, and instantly revealed the whole to her husband.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:7
verses.text: A plan was laid for detecting Maximian in the very execution of his crime.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:8
verses.text: They placed a base eunuch to be murdered instead of the emperor.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:9
verses.text: At the dead of night Maximian arose, and perceived all things to be favourable for his insidious purpose.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:10
verses.text: There were few soldiers on guard, and these too at some distance from the bed-chamber.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:11
verses.text: However, to prevent suspicion, he accosted them, and said that he had had a dream which he wished to communicate to his son-in-law.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:12
verses.text: He went in armed, slew the eunuch, sprung forth exultingly, and avowed the murder.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:13
verses.text: At that moment Constantine showed himself on the opposite side with a band of soldiers; the dead body was brought out of the bed-chamber; the murderer, taken in the fact, all aghast,  "Stood like a stone, silent and motionless;"    while Constantine upbraided him for his impiety and enormous guilt.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:14
verses.text: At last Maximian obtained leave that the manner of his death should be at his own choice, and he strangled himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 30:15
verses.text: Thus that mightiest sovereign of Rome—who ruled so long with exceeding glory, and who celebrated his twentieth anniversary—thus that most haughty man had his neck broken, and ended his detestable life by a death base and ignominious.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:2
verses.text: XXXI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:3
verses.text: From Maximian, God, the avenger of religion and of His people, turned his eyes to Galerius, the author of the accursed persecution, that in his punishment also He might manifest the power of His majesty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:4
verses.text: Galerius, too, was purposing to celebrate his twentieth anniversary; and as, under that pretext, he had, by new taxes payable in gold and silver, oppressed the provinces, so now, that he might recompense them by celebrating the promised festival, he used the like pretext for repeating his oppressions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:5
verses.text: Who can relate in fit terms the methods used to harass mankind in levying the tax, and especially with regard to corn and the other fruits of the earth? The officers, or rather the executioners, of all the different magistrates, seized on each individual, and would never let go their hold.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:6
verses.text: No man knew to whom he ought to make payment first.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:7
verses.text: There was no dispensation given to those who had nothing; and they were required, under pain of being variously tortured, instantly to pay, notwithstanding their inability.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:8
verses.text: Many guards were set round, no breathing time was granted, or, at any season of the year, the least respite from exactions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:9
verses.text: Different magistrates, or the officers of different magistrates, frequently contended for the right of levying the tax from the same persons.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:10
verses.text: No threshing-floor without a tax-gatherer, no vintage without a watch, and nought left for the sustenance of the husbandman! That food should be snatched from the mouths of those who had earned it by toil, was grievous: the hope, however, of being afterwards relieved, might have made that grievance supportable; but it was necessary for every one who appeared at the anniversary festival to provide robes of various kinds, and gold and silver besides.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 31:11
verses.text: And one might have said, "How shall I furnish myself with those things, O tyrant void of understanding, if you carry off the whole fruits of my ground, and violently seize its expected produce?" Thus, throughout the dominions of Galerius, men were spoiled of their goods, and all was raked together into the imperial treasury, that the emperor might be enabled to perform his vow of celebrating a festival which he was doomed never to celebrate.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:2
verses.text: XXXII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:3
verses.text: Maximin Daia was incensed at the nomination of Licinius to the dignity of emperor, and he would no longer be called Caesar, or allow himself to be ranked as third in authority.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:4
verses.text: Galerius, by repeated messages, besought Daia to yield, and to acquiesce in his arrangement, to give place to age, and to reverence the grey hairs of Licinius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:5
verses.text: But Daia became more and more insolent.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:6
verses.text: He urged that, as it was he who first assumed the purple, so, by possession, he had right to priority in rank; and he set at nought the entreaties and the injunctions of Galerius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:7
verses.text: That brute animal was stung to the quick, and bellowed when the mean creature whom he had made Caesar, in expectation of his thorough obsequiousness, forgot the great favour conferred on him, and impiously withstood the requests and will of his benefactor.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:8
verses.text: Galerius at length, overcome by the obstinacy of Daia, abolished the subordinate title of Caesar, gave to himself and Licinius that of the Augusti, and to Daia and Constantine that of sons of the Augusti.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:9
verses.text: Daia, some time after, in a letter to Galerius, took occasion to observe, that at the last general muster he had been saluted by his army under the title of Augustus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 32:10
verses.text: Galerius, vexed and grieved at this, commanded that all the four should have the appellation of emperor.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:2
verses.text: XXXIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:3
verses.text: And now, when Galerius was in the eighteenth year of his reign, God struck him with an incurable plague.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:4
verses.text: A malignant ulcer formed itself low down in his secret parts, and spread by degrees.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:5
verses.text: The physicians attempted to eradicate it, and healed up the place affected.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:6
verses.text: But the sore, after having been skinned over, broke out again; a vein burst, and the blood flowed in such quantity as to endanger his life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:7
verses.text: The blood, however, was stopped, although with difficulty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:8
verses.text: The physicians had to undertake their operations anew, and at length they cicatrized the wound.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:9
verses.text: In consequence of some slight motion of his body, Galerius received a hurt, and the blood streamed more abundantly than before.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:10
verses.text: He grew emaciated, pallid, and feeble, and the bleeding then stanched.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:11
verses.text: The ulcer began to be insensible to the remedies applied, and a gangrene seized all the neighbouring parts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:12
verses.text: It diffused itself the wider the more the corrupted flesh was cut away, and everything employed as the means of cure served but to aggravate the disease.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:13
verses.text: "The masters of the healing art withdrew".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:14
verses.text: Then famous physicians were brought in from all quarters; but no human means had any success.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:15
verses.text: Apollo and aesculapius were besought importunately for remedies: Apollo did prescribe, and the distemper augmented.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:16
verses.text: Already approaching to its deadly crisis, it had occupied the lower regions of his body: his bowels came out, and his whole seat putrefied.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:17
verses.text: The luckless physicians, although without hope of overcoming the malady, ceased not to apply fomentations and administer medicines.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:18
verses.text: The humours having been repelled, the distemper attacked his intestines, and worms were generated in his body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:19
verses.text: The stench was so foul as to pervade not only the palace, but even the whole city; and no wonder, for by that time the passages from his bladder and bowels, having been devoured by the worms, became indiscriminate, and his body, with intolerable anguish, was dissolved into one mass of corruption.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:20
verses.text: "Stung to the soul, he bellowed with the pain,  So roars the wounded bull".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:21
verses.text: —Pitt    They applied warm flesh of animals to the chief seat of the disease, that the warmth might draw out those minute worms; and accordingly, when the dressings were removed, there issued forth an innumerable swarm: nevertheless the prolific disease had hatched swarms much more abundant to prey upon and consume his intestines.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:22
verses.text: Already, through a complication of distempers, the different parts of his body had lost their natural form: the superior part was dry, meagre, and haggard, and his ghastly-looking skin had settled itself deep amongst his bones while the inferior, distended like bladders, retained no appearance of joints.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 33:23
verses.text: These things happened in the course of a complete year; and at length, overcome by calamities, he was obliged to acknowledge God, and he cried aloud, in the intervals of raging pain, that he would re-edify the Church which he had demolished, and make atonement for his misdeeds; and when he was near his end, he published an edict of the tenor following:—.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34:2
verses.text: XXXIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34:3
verses.text: "Amongst our other regulations for the permanent advantage of the commonweal, we have hitherto studied to reduce all things to a conformity with the ancient laws and public discipline of the Romans.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34:4
verses.text: "It has been our aim in an especial manner, that the Christians also, who had abandoned the religion of their forefathers, should return to right opinions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34:5
verses.text: For such wilfulness and folly had, we know not how, taken possession of them, that instead of observing those ancient institutions, which possibly their own forefathers had established, they, through caprice, made laws to themselves, and drew together into different societies many men of widely different persuasions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34:6
verses.text: "After the publication of our edict, ordaining the Christians to betake themselves to the observance of the ancient institutions, many of them were subdued through the fear of danger, and moreover many of them were exposed to jeopardy; nevertheless, because great numbers still persist in their opinions, and because we have perceived that at present they neither pay reverence and due adoration to the gods, nor yet worship their own God, therefore we, from our wonted clemency in bestowing pardon on all, have judged it fit to extend our indulgence to those men, and to permit them again to be Christians, and to establish the places of their religious assemblies; yet so as that they offend not against good order.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34:7
verses.text: "By another mandate we purpose to signify unto magistrates how they ought herein to demean themselves.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 34:8
verses.text: "Wherefore it will be the duty of the Christians, in consequence of this our toleration, to pray to their God for our welfare, and for that of the public, and for their own; that the commonweal may continue safe in every quarter, and that they themselves may live securely in their habitations".

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:2
verses.text: XXXV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:3
verses.text: This edict was promulgated at Nicomedia on the day preceding the kalends of May, in the eighth consulship of Galerius, and the second of Maximin Daia.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:4
verses.text: Then the prison-gates having been thrown open, you, my best beloved Donatus, together with the other confessors for the faith, were set at liberty from a jail, which had been your residence for six years.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:5
verses.text: Galerius, however, did not, by publication of this edict, obtain the divine forgiveness.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:6
verses.text: In a few days after he was consumed by the horrible disease that had brought on an universal putrefaction.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:7
verses.text: Dying, he recommended his wife and son to Licinius, and delivered them over into his hands.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:8
verses.text: This event was known at Nicomedia before the end of the month.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 35:9
verses.text: His vicennial anniversary was to have been celebrated on the ensuing kalends of March.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:2
verses.text: XXXVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:3
verses.text: Daia, on receiving this news, hasted with relays of horses from the East, to seize the dominions of Galerius, and, while Licinius lingered in Europe, to arrogate to himself all the country as far as the narrow seas of Chalcedon.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:4
verses.text: On his entry into Bithynia, he, with the view of acquiring immediate popularity, abolished Galerius' tax, to the great joy of all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:5
verses.text: Dissension arose between the two emperors, and almost an open war.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:6
verses.text: They stood on the opposite shores with their armies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:7
verses.text: Peace, however, and amity were established under certain conditions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:8
verses.text: Licinius and Daia met on the narrow sees, concluded a treaty, and in token of friendship joined hands.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:9
verses.text: Then Daia, believing all things to be in security, returned (to Nicomedia), and was in his new dominions what he had been in Syria and Egypt.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:10
verses.text: First of all, he took away the toleration and general protection granted by Galerius to the Christians, and, for this end, he secretly procured addresses from different cities, requesting that no Christian church might be built within their walls; and thus he meant to make that which was his own choice appear as if extorted from him by importunity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:11
verses.text: In compliance with those addresses, he introduced a new mode of government in things respecting religion, and for each city he created a high priest, chosen from among the persons of most distinction.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:12
verses.text: The office of those men was to make daily sacrifices to all their gods, and, with the aid of the former priests, to prevent the Christians from erecting churches, or from worshipping God either publicly or in private; and he authorized them to compel the Christians to sacrifice to idols, and, on their refusal, to bring them before the civil magistrate; and, as if this had not been enough, in every province he established a superintendent priest, one of chief eminence in the state; and he commanded that all those priests newly instituted should appear in white habits, that being the most honourable distinction of dress.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:13
verses.text: And as to the Christians, he purposed to follow the course that he had followed in the East, and, affecting the show of clemency, he forbade the slaying of God's servants, but he gave command that they should be mutilated.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 36:14
verses.text: So the confessors for the faith had their ears and nostrils slit, their hands and feet lopped off, and their eyes dug out of the sockets.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:2
verses.text: XXXVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:3
verses.text: While occupied in this plan, he received letters from Constantine which deterred him from proceeding in its execution, so for a time he dissembled his purpose; nevertheless any Christian that fell within his power was privily thrown into the sea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:4
verses.text: Neither did he cease from his custom of sacrificing every day in the palace.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:5
verses.text: It was also an invention of his to cause all animals used for food to be slaughtered, not by cooks, but by priests at the altars; so that nothing was ever served up, unless foretasted, consecrated, and sprinkled with wine, according to the rites of paganism; and whoever was invited to an entertainment must needs have returned from it impure and defiled.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:6
verses.text: In all things else he resembled his preceptor Galerius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:7
verses.text: For if aught chanced to have been left untouched by Diocles and Maximian, that did Daia greedily and shamelessly carry off.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:8
verses.text: And now the granaries of each individual were shut, and all warehouses sealed up, and taxes, not yet due, were levied by anticipation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:9
verses.text: Hence famine, from neglect of cultivation, and the prices of all things enhanced beyond measure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:10
verses.text: Herds and flocks were driven from their pasture for the daily sacrifice.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:11
verses.text: By gorging his soldiers with the flesh of sacrifices, he so corrupted them, that they disdained their wonted pittance in corn, and wantonly threw it away.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:12
verses.text: Meanwhile Daia recompensed his bodyguards, who were very numerous, with costly raiment and gold medals, made donatives in silver to the common soldiers and recruits, and bestowed every sort of largess on the barbarians who served in his army.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 37:13
verses.text: As to grants of the property of living persons, which he made to his favourites whenever they chose to ask what belonged to another, I know not whether the same thanks might not be due to him that are given to merciful robbers, who spoil without murdering.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:2
verses.text: XXXVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:3
verses.text: But that which distinguished his character, and in which he transcended all former emperors, was his desire of debauching women.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:4
verses.text: What else can I call it but a blind and headstrong passion? Yet such epithets feebly express my indignation in reciting his enormities.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:5
verses.text: The magnitude of the guilt overpowers my tongue, and makes it unequal to its office.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:6
verses.text: Eunuchs and panders made search everywhere, and no sooner was any comely face discovered, than husbands and parents were obliged to withdraw.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:7
verses.text: Matrons of quality and virgins were stripped of their robes, and all their limbs were inspected, lest any part should be unworthy of the bed of the emperor.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:8
verses.text: Whenever a woman resisted, death by drowning was inflicted on her; as if, under the reign of this adulterer, chastity had been treason.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:9
verses.text: Some men there were, who, beholding the violation of wives whom for virtue and fidelity they affectionately loved, could not endure their anguish of mind, and so killed themselves.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:10
verses.text: While this monster ruled, it was singular deformity alone which could shield the honour of any female from his savage desires.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:11
verses.text: At length he introduced a custom prohibiting marriage unless with the imperial permission; and he made this an instrument to serve the purposes of his lewdness.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:12
verses.text: After having debauched freeborn maidens, he gave them for wives to his slaves.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:13
verses.text: His conflicts also imitated the example of the emperor, and violated with impunity the beds of their dependants.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:14
verses.text: For who was there to punish such offences? As for the daughters of men of middle rank, any who were inclined took them by force.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:15
verses.text: Ladies of quality, who could not be taken by force, were petitioned for, and obtained from the emperor by way of free gift.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:16
verses.text: Nor could a father oppose this; for the imperial warrant having been once signed, he had no alternative but to die, or to receive some barbarian as his son-in-law.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:17
verses.text: For hardly was there any person in the lifeguard except of those people, who, having been driven from their habitations by the Goths in the twentieth year of Diocletian, yielded themselves to Galerius and entered into his service.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:18
verses.text: It was ill for humankind, that men who had fled from the bondage of barbarians should thus come to lord it over the Romans.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 38:19
verses.text: Environed by such guards, Daia oppressed and insulted the Eastern empire.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:2
verses.text: XXXIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:3
verses.text: Now Daia, in gratifying his libidinous desires, made his own will the standard of right; and therefore he would not refrain from soliciting the widow of Galerius, the Empress Valeria, to whom he had lately given the appellation of mother.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:4
verses.text: After the death of her husband, she had repaired to Daia, because she imagined that she might live with more security in his dominions than elsewhere, especially as he was a married man; but the flagitious creature became instantly inflamed with a passion for her.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:5
verses.text: Valeria was still in weeds, the time of her mourning not being yet expired.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:6
verses.text: He sent a message to her proposing marriage, and offering, on her compliance, to put away his wife.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:7
verses.text: She frankly returned an answer such as she alone could dare to do: first, that she would not treat of marriage while she was in weeds, and while the ashes of Galerius, her husband, and, by adoption, the father of Daia, were yet warm; next, that he acted impiously, in proposing to divorce a faithful wife to make room for another, whom in her turn he would also cast off; and, lastly, that it was indecent, unexampled, and unlawful for a woman of her title and dignity to engage a second time in wedlock.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:8
verses.text: This bold answer having been reported to Daia, presently his desires changed into rage and furious resentment.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 39:9
verses.text: He pronounced sentence of forfeiture against the princess, seized her goods, removed her attendants, tortured her eunuchs to death, and banished her and her mother Prisca: but he appointed no particular place for her residence while in banishment; and hence he insultingly expelled her from every abode that she took in the course of her wanderings; and, to complete all, he condemned the ladies who enjoyed most of her friendship and confidence to die on a false accusation of adultery.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:2
verses.text: XL.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:3
verses.text: There was a certain matron of high rank who already had grandchildren by more than one son.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:4
verses.text: Her Valeria loved like a second mother, and Daia suspected that her advice had produced that refusal which Valeria gave to his matrimonial offers; and therefore he charged the president Eratineus to have her put to death in a way that might injure her fame.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:5
verses.text: To her two others, equally noble, were added.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:6
verses.text: One of them, who had a daughter a Vestal virgin at Rome, maintained an intercourse by stealth with the banished Valeria.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:7
verses.text: The other, married to a senator, was intimately connected with the empress.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:8
verses.text: Excellent beauty and virtue proved the cause of their death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:9
verses.text: They were dragged to the tribunal, not of an upright judge, but of a robber.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:10
verses.text: Neither indeed was there any accuser, until a certain Jew, one charged with other offences, was induced, through hope of pardon, to give false evidence against the innocent.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:11
verses.text: The equitable and vigilant magistrate conducted him out of the city under a guard, lest the populace should have stoned him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:12
verses.text: This tragedy was acted at Nicaea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:13
verses.text: The Jew was ordered to the torture till he should speak as he had been instructed, while the torturers by blows prevented the women from speaking in their own defence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:14
verses.text: The innocent were condemned to die.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:15
verses.text: Then there arose wailing and lamentation, not only of the senator, who attended on his well-deserving consort, but amongst the spectators also, whom this proceeding, scandalous and unheard of, had brought together; and, to prevent the multitude from violently rescuing the condemned persons out of the hands of the executioners, military commanders followed with light infantry and archers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:16
verses.text: And thus, under a guard of armed soldiers, they were led to punishment.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:17
verses.text: Their domestics having been forced to flee, they would have remained without burial, had not the compassion of friends interred them by stealth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 40:18
verses.text: Nor was the promise of pardon made good to the feigned adulterer, for he was fixed to a gibbet, and then he disclosed the whole secret contrivance; and with his last breath he protested to all the beholders that the women died innocent.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41:2
verses.text: XLI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41:3
verses.text: But the empress, an exile in some desert region of Syria, secretly informed her father Diocletian of the calamity that had befallen her.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41:4
verses.text: He despatched messengers to Daia, requesting that his daughter might be sent to him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41:5
verses.text: He could not prevail.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41:6
verses.text: Again and again he entreated; yet she was not sent.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41:7
verses.text: At length he employed a relation of his, a military man high in power and authority, to implore Daia by the remembrance of past favours.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 41:8
verses.text: This messenger, equally unsuccessful in his negotiation as the others, reported to Diocletian that his prayers were vain.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 42

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 42:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 42:2
verses.text: XLII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 42:3
verses.text: At this time, by command of Constantine, the statues of Maximian Herculius were thrown down, and his portraits removed; and, as the two old emperors were generally delineated in one piece, the portraits of both were removed at the same time.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 42:4
verses.text: Thus Diocletian lived to see a disgrace which no former emperor had ever seen, and, under the double load of vexation of spirit and bodily maladies, he resolved to die.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 42:5
verses.text: Tossing to and fro, with his soul agitated by grief, he could neither eat nor take rest.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 42:6
verses.text: He sighed, groaned, and wept often, and incessantly threw himself into various postures, now on his couch, and now on the ground.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 42:7
verses.text: So he, who for twenty years was the most prosperous of emperors, having been cast down into the obscurity of a private station, treated in the most contumelious manner, and compelled to abhor life, became incapable of receiving nourishment, and, worn out with anguish of mind, expired.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:2
verses.text: XLIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:3
verses.text: Of the adversaries of God there still remained one, whose overthrow and end I am now to relate.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:4
verses.text: Daia had entertained jealousy and ill-will against Licinius from the time that the preference was given to him by Galerius; and those sentiments still subsisted, notwithstanding the treaty of peace lately concluded between them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:5
verses.text: When Daia heard that the sister of Constantine was betrothed to Licinius, he apprehended that the two emperors, by contracting this affinity, meant to league against him; so he privily sent ambassadors to Rome, desiring a friendly alliance with Maxentius: he also wrote to him in terms of cordiality.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:6
verses.text: The ambassadors were received courteously, friendship established, and in token of it the effigies of Maxentius and Daia were placed together in public view.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:7
verses.text: Maxentius willingly embraced this, as if it had been an aid from heaven; for he had already declared war against Constantine, as if to revenge the death of his father Maximian.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:8
verses.text: From this appearance of filial piety a suspicion arose, that the detestable old man had but feigned a quarrel with his son that he might have an opportunity to destroy his rivals in power, and so make way for himself and his son to possess the whole empire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 43:9
verses.text: This conjecture, however, had no foundation; for his true purpose was to have destroyed his son and the others, and then to have reinstated himself and Diocletian in sovereign authority.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:2
verses.text: XLIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:3
verses.text: And now a civil war broke out between Constantine and Maxentius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:4
verses.text: Although Maxentius kept himself within Rome, because the soothsayers had foretold that if he went out of it he should perish, yet he conducted the military operations by able generals.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:5
verses.text: In forces he exceeded his adversary; for he had not only his father's army, which deserted from Severus, but also his own, which he had lately drawn together out of Mauritania and Italy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:6
verses.text: They fought, and the troops of Maxentius prevailed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:7
verses.text: At length Constantine, with steady courage and a mind prepared for every event, led his whole forces to the neighbourhood of Rome, and encamped them opposite to the Milvian bridge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:8
verses.text: The anniversary of the reign of Maxentius approached, that is, the sixth of the kalends of November, and the fifth year of his reign was drawing to an end.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:9
verses.text: Constantine was directed in a dream to cause the heavenly sign to be delineated on the shields of his soldiers, and so to proceed to battle.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:10
verses.text: He did as he had been commanded, and he marked on their shields the letter Χ, with a perpendicular line drawn through it and turned round thus at the top, being the cipher of Christ.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:11
verses.text: Having this sign (ΧР ), his troops stood to arms.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:12
verses.text: The enemies advanced, but without their emperor, and they crossed the bridge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:13
verses.text: The armies met, and fought with the utmost exertions of valour, and firmly maintained their ground.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:14
verses.text: In the meantime a sedition arose at Rome, and Maxentius was reviled as one who had abandoned all concern for the safety of the commonweal; and suddenly, while he exhibited the Circensian games on the anniversary of his reign, the people cried with one voice, "Constantine cannot be overcome!" Dismayed at this, Maxentius burst from the assembly, and having called some senators together, ordered the Sibylline books to be searched.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:15
verses.text: In them it was found that:—  "On the same day the enemy of the Romans should perish".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:16
verses.text: Led by this response to the hopes of victory, he went to the field.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:17
verses.text: The bridge in his rear was broken down.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:18
verses.text: At sight of that the battle grew hotter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:19
verses.text: The hand of the Lord prevailed, and the forces of Maxentius were routed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:20
verses.text: He fled towards the broken bridge; but the multitude pressing on him, he was driven headlong into the Tiber.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:21
verses.text: This destructive war being ended, Constantine was acknowledged as emperor, with great rejoicings, by the senate and people of Rome.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:22
verses.text: And now he came to know the perfidy of Daia; for he found the letters written to Maxentius, and saw the statues and portraits of the two associates which had been set up together.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:23
verses.text: The senate, in reward of the valour of Constantine, decreed to him the title of Maximus (the Greatest), a title which Daia had always arrogated to himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 44:24
verses.text: Daia, when he heard that Constantine was victorious and Rome freed, expressed as much sorrow as if he himself had been vanquished; but afterwards, when he heard of the decree of the senate, he grew outrageous, avowed enmity towards Constantine, and made his title of the Greatest a theme of abuse and raillery.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:2
verses.text: XLV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:3
verses.text: Constantine having settled all things at Rome, went to Milan about the beginning of winter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:4
verses.text: Thither also Licinius came to receive his wife Constantia.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:5
verses.text: When Daia understood that they were busied in solemnizing the nuptials, he moved out of Syria in the depth of a severe winter, and by forced marches he came into Bithynia with an army much impaired; for he lost all his beasts of burden, of whatever kind, in consequence of excessive rains and snow, miry ways, cold and fatigue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:6
verses.text: Their carcases, scattered about the roads, seemed an emblem of the calamities of the impending war, and the presage of a like destruction that awaited the soldiers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:7
verses.text: Daia did not halt in his own territories; but immediately crossed the Thracian Bosphorus, and in a hostile manner approached the gates of Byzantium.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:8
verses.text: There was a garrison in the city, established by Licinius to check any invasion that Daia might make.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:9
verses.text: At first Daia attempted to entice the soldiers by the promise of donatives, and then to intimidate them by assault and storm.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:10
verses.text: Yet neither promises nor force availed aught.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:11
verses.text: After eleven days had elapsed, within which time Licinius might have learned the state of the garrison, the soldiers surrendered, not through treachery, but because they were too weak to make a longer resistance.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:12
verses.text: Then Daia moved on to Heraclea (otherwise called Perinthus), and by delays of the like nature before that place lost some days.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:13
verses.text: And now Licinius by expeditious marches had reached Adrianople, but with forces not numerous.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:14
verses.text: Then Daia, having taken Perinthus by capitulation, and remained there for a short space, moved forwards eighteen miles to the first station.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:15
verses.text: Here his progress was stopped; for Licinius had already occupied the second station, at the distance also of eighteen miles.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 45:16
verses.text: Licinius, having assembled what forces he could from the neighbouring quarters, advanced towards Daia rather indeed to retard his operations than with any purpose of fighting, or hope of victory: for Daia had an army of seventy thousand men, while he himself had scarce thirty thousand; for his soldiers being dispersed in various regions, there was not time, on that sudden emergency, to collect all of them together.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:2
verses.text: XLVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:3
verses.text: The armies thus approaching each other, seemed on the eve of a battle.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:4
verses.text: Then Daia made this vow to Jupiter, that if he obtained victory he would extinguish and utterly efface the name of the Christians.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:5
verses.text: And on the following night an angel of the Lord seemed to stand before Licinius while he was asleep, admonishing him to arise immediately, and with his whole army to put up a prayer to the Supreme God, and assuring him that by so doing he should obtain victory.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:6
verses.text: Licinius fancied that, hearing this, he arose, and that his monitor, who was nigh him, directed how be should pray, and in what words.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:7
verses.text: Awaking from sleep, he sent for one of his secretaries, and dictated these words exactly as he had heard them:—  "Supreme God, we beseech Thee; Holy God, we beseech Thee; unto Thee we commend all right; unto Thee we commend our safety; unto Thee we commend our empire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:8
verses.text: By Thee we live, by Thee we are victorious and happy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:9
verses.text: Supreme Holy God, hear our prayers; to Thee we stretch forth our arms.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:10
verses.text: Hear, Holy Supreme God".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:11
verses.text: Many copies were made of these words, and distributed amongst the principal commanders, who were to teach them to the soldiers under their charge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:12
verses.text: At this all men took fresh courage, in the confidence that victory bad been announced to them from heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:13
verses.text: Licinius resolved to give battle on the kalends of May; for precisely eight years before Daia had received the dignity of Caesar, and Licinius chose that day in hopes that Daia might be vanquished on the anniversary of his reign, as Maxentius had been on his.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:14
verses.text: Daia, however, purposed to give battle earlier, to fight on the day before those kalends, and to triumph on the anniversary of his reign.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:15
verses.text: Accounts came that Daia was in motion; the soldiers of Licinius armed themselves; and advanced.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:16
verses.text: A barren and open plain, called Campus Serenus, lay between the two armies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:17
verses.text: They were now in sight of one another.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:18
verses.text: The soldiers of Licinius placed their shields on the ground, took off their helmets, and, following the example of their leaders, stretched forth their hands towards heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:19
verses.text: Then the emperor uttered the prayer, and they all repeated it after him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:20
verses.text: The host, doomed to speedy destruction, heard the murmur of the prayers of their adversaries.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:21
verses.text: And now, the ceremony having been thrice performed, the soldiers of Licinius became full of courage, buckled on their helmets again, and resumed their shields.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:22
verses.text: The two emperors advanced to a conference: but Daia could not be brought to peace; for he held Licinius in contempt, and imagined that the soldiers would presently abandon an emperor parsimonious in his donatives, and enter into the service of one liberal even to profusion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:23
verses.text: And indeed it was on this notion that he began the war.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 46:24
verses.text: He looked for the voluntary surrender of the armies of Licinius; and, thus reinforced, he meant forthwith to have attacked Constantine.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:2
verses.text: XLVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:3
verses.text: So the two armies drew nigh; the trumpets gave the signal; the military ensigns advanced; the troops of Licinius charged.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:4
verses.text: But the enemies, panic-struck, could neither draw their swords nor yet throw their javelins.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:5
verses.text: Daia went about, and, alternately by entreaties and promises, attempted to seduce the soldiers of Licinius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:6
verses.text: But he was not hearkened to in any quarter, and they drove him back.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:7
verses.text: Then were the troops of Daia slaughtered, none making resistance; and such numerous legions, and forces so mighty, were mowed down by an inferior enemy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:8
verses.text: No one called to mind his reputation, or former valour, or the honourable rewards which had been conferred on him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:9
verses.text: The Supreme God did so place their necks under the sword of their foes, that they seemed to have entered the field, not as combatants, but as men devoted to death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:10
verses.text: After great numbers had fallen, Daia perceived that everything went contrary to his hopes; and therefore he threw aside the purple, and having put on the habit of a slave, hasted across the Thracian Bosphorus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:11
verses.text: One half of his army perished in battle, and the rest either surrendered to the victor or fled; for now that the emperor himself had deserted, there seemed to be no shame in desertion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:12
verses.text: Before the expiration of the kalends of May, Daia arrived at Nicomedia, although distant one hundred and sixty miles from the field of battle.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:13
verses.text: So in the space of one day and two nights he performed that journey.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 47:14
verses.text: Having hurried away with his children and wife, and a few officers of his court, he went towards Syria; but having been joined by some troops from those quarters, and having collected together a part of his fugitive forces, he halted in Cappadocia, and then he resumed the imperial garb.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:2
verses.text: XLVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:3
verses.text: Not many days after the victory, Licinius, having received part of the soldiers of Daia into his service, and properly distributed them, transported his army into Bithynia, and having made his entry into Nicomedia, he returned thanks to God, through whose aid he had overcome; and on the ides of June, while he and Constantine were consuls for the third time, he commanded the following edict for the restoration of the Church, directed to the president of the province, to be promulgated:—  "When we, Constantine and Licinius, emperors, had an interview at Milan, and conferred together with respect to the good and security of the commonweal, it seemed to us that, amongst those things that are profitable to mankind in general, the reverence paid to the Divinity merited our first and chief attention, and that it was proper that the Christians and all others should have liberty to follow that mode of religion which to each of them appeared best; so that that God, who is seated in heaven, might be benign and propitious to us, and to every one under our government.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:4
verses.text: And therefore we judged it a salutary measure, and one highly consonant to right reason, that no man should be denied leave of attaching himself to the rites of the Christians, or to whatever other religion his mind directed him, that thus the supreme Divinity, to whose worship we freely devote ourselves, might continue to vouchsafe His favour and beneficence to us.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:5
verses.text: And accordingly we give you to know that, without regard to any provisos in our former orders to you concerning the Christians, all who choose that religion are to be permitted, freely and absolutely, to remain in it, and not to be disturbed any ways, or molested.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:6
verses.text: And we thought fit to be thus special in the things committed to your charge, that you might understand that the indulgence which we have granted in matters of religion to the Christians is ample and unconditional; and perceive at the same time that the open and free exercise of their respective religions is granted to all others, as well as to the Christians.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:7
verses.text: For it befits the well-ordered state and the tranquillity of our times that each individual be allowed, according to his own choice, to worship the Divinity; and we mean not to derogate aught from the honour due to any religion or its votaries.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:8
verses.text: Moreover, with respect to the Christians, we formerly gave certain orders concerning the places appropriated for their religious assemblies; but now we will that all persons who have purchased such places, either from our exchequer or from any one else, do restore them to the Christians, without money demanded or price claimed, and that this be performed peremptorily and unambiguously; and we will also, that they who have obtained any right to such places by form of gift do forthwith restore them to the Christians: reserving always to such persons, who have either purchased for a price, or gratuitously acquired them, to make application to the judge of the district, if they look on themselves as entitled to any equivalent from our beneficence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:9
verses.text: "All those places are, by your intervention, to be immediately restored to the Christians.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:10
verses.text: And because it appears that, besides the places appropriated to religious worship, the Christians did possess other places, which belonged not to individuals, but to their society in general, that is, to their churches, we comprehend all such within the regulation aforesaid, and we will that you cause them all to be restored to the society or churches, and that without hesitation or controversy: Provided always, that the persons making restitution without a price paid shall be at liberty to seek indemnification from our bounty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:11
verses.text: In furthering all which things for the behoof of the Christians, you are to use your utmost diligence, to the end that our orders be speedily obeyed, and our gracious purpose in securing the public tranquillity promoted.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:12
verses.text: So shall that divine favour which, in affairs of the mightiest importance, we have already experienced, continue to give success to us, and in our successes make the commonweal happy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:13
