verses.text: And that the tenor of this our gracious ordinance may be made known unto all, we will that you cause it by your authority to be published everywhere".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:14
verses.text: Licinius having issued this ordinance, made an harangue, in which he exhorted the Christians to rebuild their religious edifices.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 48:15
verses.text: And thus, from the overthrow of the Church until its restoration, there was a space of ten years and about four months.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:2
verses.text: XLIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:3
verses.text: While Licinius pursued with his army, the fugitive tyrant retreated, and again occupied the passes of mount Taurus; and there, by erecting parapets and towers, attempted to stop the march of Licinius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:4
verses.text: But the victorious troops, by an attack made on the right, broke through all obstacles, and Daia at length fled to Tarsus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:5
verses.text: There, being hard pressed both by sea and land, he despaired of finding any place for refuge; and in the anguish and dismay of his mind, he sought death as the only remedy of those calamities that God had heaped on him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:6
verses.text: But first he gorged himself with food, and large draughts of wine, as those are wont who believe that they eat and drink for the last time; and so he swallowed poison.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:7
verses.text: However, the force of the poison, repelled by his full stomach, could not immediately operate, but it produced a grievous disease, resembling the pestilence; and his life was prolonged only that his sufferings might be more severe.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:8
verses.text: And now the poison began to rage, and to burn up everything within him, so that he was driven to distraction with the intolerable pain; and during a fit of frenzy, which lasted four days, he gathered handfuls of earth, and greedily devoured it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:9
verses.text: Having undergone various and excruciating torments, he dashed his forehead against the wall, and his eyes started out of their sockets.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:10
verses.text: And now, become blind, he imagined that he saw God, with His servants arrayed in white robes, sitting in judgment on him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:11
verses.text: He roared out as men on the rack are wont, and exclaimed that not he, but others, were guilty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:12
verses.text: In the end, as if he had been racked into confession, he acknowledged his own guilt, and lamentably implored Christ to have mercy upon him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 49:13
verses.text: Then, amidst groans, like those of one burnt alive, did he breathe out his guilty soul in the most horrible kind of death.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:2
verses.text: L.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:3
verses.text: Thus did God subdue all those who persecuted His name, so that neither root nor branch of them remained; for Licinius, as soon as he was established in sovereign authority, commanded that Valeria should be put to death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:4
verses.text: Daia, although exasperated against her, never ventured to do this, not even after his discomfiture and flight, and when he knew that his end approached.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:5
verses.text: Licinius commanded that Candidianus also should be put to death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:6
verses.text: He was the son of Galerius by a concubine, and Valeria, having no children, had adopted him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:7
verses.text: On the news of the death of Daia, she came in disguise to the court of Licinius, anxious to observe what might befall Candidianus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:8
verses.text: The youth, presenting himself at Nicomedia, had an outward show of honour paid to him, and, while he suspected no harm, was killed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:9
verses.text: Hearing of this catastrophe, Valeria immediately fled.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:10
verses.text: The Emperor Severus left a son, Severianus, arrived at man's estate, who accompanied Daia in his flight from the field of battle.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:11
verses.text: Licinius caused him to be condemned and executed, under the pretence that, on the death of Daia, he had intentions of assuming the imperial purple.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:12
verses.text: Long before this time, Candidianus and Severianus, apprehending evil from Licinius, had chosen to remain with Daia; while Valeria favoured Licinius, and was willing to bestow on him that which she had denied to Daia, all rights accruing to her as the widow of Galerius.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:13
verses.text: Licinius also put to death Maximus, the son of Daia, a boy eight years old, and a daughter of Daia, who was seven years old, and had been betrothed to Candidianus.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:14
verses.text: But before their death, their mother had been thrown into the Orontes, in which river she herself had frequently commanded chaste women to be drowned.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 50:15
verses.text: So, by the unerring and just judgment of God, all the impious received according to the deeds that they had done.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 51

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 51:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 51:2
verses.text: LI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 51:3
verses.text: Valeria, too, who for fifteen months had wandered under a mean garb from province to province, was at length discovered in Thessalonica, was apprehended, together with her mother Prisca, and suffered capital punishment.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 51:4
verses.text: Both the ladies were conducted to execution; a fall from grandeur which moved the pity of the multitude of beholders that the strange sight had gathered together.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 51:5
verses.text: They were beheaded, and their bodies cast into the sea.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 51:6
verses.text: Thus the chaste demeanour of Valeria, and the high rank of her and her mother, proved fatal to both of them.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 52

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 52:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 52:2
verses.text: LII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 52:3
verses.text: I relate all those things on the authority of well-informed persons; and I thought it proper to commit them to writing exactly as they happened, lest the memory of events so important should perish, and lest any future historian of the persecutors should corrupt the truth, either by suppressing their offences against God, or the judgment of God against them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 52:4
verses.text: To His everlasting mercy ought we to render thanks, that, having at length looked on the earth, He deigned to collect again and to restore His flock, partly laid waste by ravenous wolves, and partly scattered abroad, and to extirpate those noxious wild beasts who had trod down its pastures, and destroyed its resting-places.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 52:5
verses.text: Where now are the surnames of the Jovii and the Herculii, once so glorious and renowned amongst the nations; surnames insolently assumed at first by Diocles and Maximian, and afterwards transferred to their successors? The Lord has blotted them out and erased them from the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 52:6
verses.text: Let us therefore with exultation celebrate the triumphs of God, and oftentimes with praises make mention of His victory; let us in our prayers, by night and by day, beseech Him to confirm for ever that peace which, after a warfare of ten years, He has bestowed on His own: and do you, above all others, my best beloved Donatus, who so well deserve to be heard, implore the Lord that it would please Him propitiously and mercifully to continue His pity towards His servants, to protect His people from the machinations and assaults of the devil, and to guard the now flourishing churches in perpetual felicity.

chapters.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:1
verses.text: Elucidation  (On the tenth of the kalends of April, p.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:2
verses.text: )  Serious difficulties are encountered by the learned in reconciling Lactantius with himself, if, indeed, the fault be not one of his copyists rather than his own.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:3
verses.text: In the fourth book of the Institutes his language is thus given by Baluzius:—  "Extremis temporibus Tiberii Caesaris, ut scriptum legimus, Dominus noster Jesus Christus, a Judaeis cruciatus est post diem decimum kalendarum Aprilis, duobus Geminis consulibus".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:4
verses.text: Lactantius was writing in Nicomedia, and may have quoted from memory what he had read, perhaps in the report of Pilate himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:5
verses.text: The expression post diem decimum kalendarum Aprilis is ambiguous: and Jarvis says, "My impression is, that it means 'after the tenth day before the kalends of April;' that is, after the d of March".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:6
verses.text: But here our author says, according to the accurate edition of Walchius (a.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:7
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:8
verses.text: ),—  "Exinde tetrarchas habuerunt usque ad Herodem, qui fuit sub imperio Tiberii Caesaris: cujus anno quinto decimo, id est duobus Geminis consulibus, ante diem septimam Calendarum Aprilium, Judaei Christum cruci affixerunt".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:9
verses.text: But here, on the authority of forty manuscripts, Du Fresnoy reads, "ante diem decimam," which he labours to reconcile with "post diem decimum," as above.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:10
verses.text: Jarvis adheres to the reading septimam, supported by more than fifty manuscripts, and decides for the d of March.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:11
verses.text: He cites Augustine to the same effect in the noted passage:—  "Ille autem mense conceptum et passum esse Christum, et Paschae observatio et dies ecclesiis notissimus Nativitatis ejus ostendit.

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:12
verses.text: Qui enim mense nono natus est octavo kalendas Janvarias profecto mense primo conceptus est circa octavum kalendas Aprilis, quod tempus passionis ejus fuit".

verses.name: Lactantius: Of the Manner in Which the Persecutors Died 53:13
verses.text: This, Augustine considers to be "seething a kid in mother's milk," after a mystical sense; cruelly making the cross to coincide with the maternity of the Virgin, who beheld her Son an innocent victim on the anniversary of her salutation by the angel.
